III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements
Section
Description • (2) All the following must be in the case record before a
youth is placed in independent living:
• (a) How the youth meets the eligibility requirements
for the specific program the youth is being placed
into.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth is currently in the ER due to their second overdose in a
month. Youth is suicidal. There is a concern for the youth's
appropriateness in Independent Living. It is unknown if there was
safety planning completed after the first overdose.
Investigation Chief Administrator was contacted on 4/28/2025 via email. He
reported he was at a conference and provided Program
Manager’s contact information for her to assist with staff contact
information who were familiar with the allegations. He also
provided his personal cell phone number in case any additional
information was needed.
Program Manager was interviewed on 4/28/2025 via email.
She provided staff contact information who was familiar with the
complaint allegation.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed on 4/28/2025
via email. She reported in the email that Independent Living
Youth (ILY) did not overdose twice while placed in their care, but
once. Regarding safety planning after ILY’s first attempt of
overdosing, the FCS reported the agency was not assigned to the
case and was not responsible for ILY safety planning during that
time as ILY was in the care of his biological mother. Foster Care
Supervisor referred this Consultant to the Foster Care Worker for
more information regarding dates and accurate information on
ILY.
Complainant was interviewed on 5/2/2025 via telephone. She
reported ILY was in the hospital for the second time due to
2

suicidal attempts. She said she is concerned about his safety and
mental well-being. She reported she was in the emergency room
when ILY came into the hospital. She reported when ILY left the
hospital, he was stable. Complainant reported ILY was monitored
due to him trying to take more than his prescribed medications.
She reported ILY is still having suicidal ideations. She reported
the hospital waited for an inpatient bed before being released.
Complainant reported ILY was awake and alert before discharge
and he did not overdose and did not need his stomach pumped.
She reported the discharge recommendation for ILY was for him
to be discharged to an inpatient bed when one was located. She
had no additional information to provide.
Placement Collaboration Unit (PCU) meeting was held on
5/8/2025. In attendance were MDHHS/PCU Supervisor and Foster
Care Worker, Foster Care Supervisor and this Consultant. This
meeting was a follow up to discuss contact with Foster Parent,
youth, safety plan and the allegation of ILY and planning
placement moving forward.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed on 4/28/2025 and
5/12/2025 via telephone. FCW reported ILY first overdose did
not occur during the foster care case and this was prior to his
removal from his Birth Mother. She explained during this time, the
alleged overdose occurred on 2/8/2025 and this was not an
overdose on his prescribed medications, ILY took an abundance
of Benadryl. FCW reported ILY was seen at the hospital when the
first overdose occurred.
FCW explained ILY went to the emergency room on 4/24/2025
due to taking his prescribed medication and feeling suicidal. She
reported Foster Parent did not know how many pills, if any, ILY
had taken. FCW said when she spoke with ILY, he reported he
was not sure how many pills he had taken and taking the
medication was a result of breaking up with his girlfriend and he
felt depressed.
FCW reported ILY was discharged from the hospital on 4/26/2025
and went to an inpatient hospitalization program. She reported
ILY was in patient from 4/26/2025 until 5/5/2025. She said he
returned to his IL placement with Foster Parent where he remains
with a safety plan. FCW said she met with Foster Parent and ILY
on 5/8/2025, with his prescribed medications and his written safety
plan. She said after reviewing the safety plan and making sure
both parties understood the safety plan, it was signed by all
stating they agreed to all of the steps, and she presented a copy
3

to the Foster Parent and ILY. FCW said she discussed with ILY
the three medications and provided the lock box the medications
are to be stored in at all times. She said there were no questions
asked by ILY or Foster Parent. FCW said Foster Parent reported
she felt very comfortable with ILY being back in his placement.
ILY reported he was very happy to be back at home with Foster
Parent and that he was doing well.
Independent Living Youth (ILY) was interviewed via telephone
on 6/23/2025. He reported he was feeling well and was taking his
medication as prescribed. He reported he is happy in his
placement. He explained that his medications are locked at all
times and given to him by Foster Parent. He reported he is also
following his safety plan. He reported he is transported to his
doctor’s appointments by his FCW due to Foster Parent’s car
currently not working. He added no additional information.
Foster Parent (FP) was interviewed via telephone on
6/23/2025. Foster Parent reported ILY was placed back into his IL
Placement on 5/5/2025 after being discharged from inpatient
treatment. She reported ILY is doing very well. She described
ILY as a perfect kid and he is not having any problems. She said
he is attending all of his counseling sessions. Foster Parent
reported Foster Care Worker transports ILY to any of his
appointments that are not virtual. She said his counseling
sessions are virtual. Foster Parent reported she has just put her
car in the shop after needing services for three or four months.
She reported that she is following ILY’s safety plan, and she
provides ILY with his daily doses of medications. She said ILY’s
medication is always under lock and key, and she is the only one
who has access to his medications. Foster Parent said the only
thing she wants at this time for ILY is for him to take drivers
training classes because she wants him to get his driver’s license.
She had no additional information.
Document Reviewed:
• ILY case file in MiSACWIS. He has two placements, one with
his elderly sister and his current placement in independent living
program with his support caregiver/Foster Parent. ILY is
prescribed three medications which are Abilify, Lexapro, and
Hydroxyzine. He is diagnosed with having major depressive
disorder, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder predominately
inattentive presentation and autism spectrum disorder.
• Safety plan dated 5/8/2025. This plan states: FP will take ILY
to ER or contact LE if needed; ILY will speak with his elderly sister
when escalated; when ILY has feelings of self-harm he will call
4

the crisis hotline and communicate his feeling with FP: FP will
administer all medications to ILY and make sure the medication is
swallowed; FP will complete random room checks; FP will keep all
medication in lock box and place it in her room when finish giving
it to ILY; ensure that no one is leaving any medication out
including over the counter medication; if FP is noticing any type of
concerning signs regarding ILY, his bedroom door will remain
open and FP will monitor ILY; when ILY is home FP will keep
frequent checks on him and ILY will utilize his coping skills when
triggered.
• Emergency Department discharge paperwork dated
4/26/2025. Discharge paperwork states ILY was admitted due to
intentional overdose on allergy medication. took approximately 30
pills but is unsure of how many different pills. ILY said he took the
pills due to a breakup. ILY was “well appearing, no clonus or
muscle rigidity noted. Recommended psychiatric hospital once
observation period was completed at Hospital. The case was
followed by poison control and was medically cleared to be
transported to Havenwyck inpatient hospital. ILY had over forty
types of tests performed from his blood work at Hospital
laboratory. All test results were returned with negative results.
• MDHHS eligibility requirement for ILY placement was
reviewed. FC worker and FC supervisor met with ILY privately in
a visitation room at the department to inquire about relatives,
fictive kin, neighbors, friends, etc. who might be able to take
placement. ILY identified his current Foster Parent. Foster Care
Supervisor contacted Foster Parent, and the Foster Parent knew
ILY and requested placement of ILY. Background information was
collected, and a thorough assessment was completed of the foster
home and Foster Parent. Upon clearance of background checks,
criminal history checks, a safety plan was put in place that ILY
birth mother could not enter or come to the home, ILY was place
with his current Foster Parent. Additional paperwork and family
team meeting followed.
• Initial Service Plan dated 3/19/2025 – 4/17/2025 written by
FCW wrote that A FTM was held and the agency efforts to place
the child(ren) in a permanent placement in a timely manner was
decided among the participants attending the meeting. It was
decided that ILY was placed in a licensed foster home at the time
of removal on 3/19/2025 as an emergency overnight placement.
On 3/20/2025 ILY was placed with a supportive adult in an
Independent Living Placement. Independent Living documents
were reviewed and presented to ILY and explained to ILY by the
FCW. Due to ILY age and being a temporary court ward, he met
the Placement Selection and Standards MDHHS FOM 722- 03
eligibility requirements for independent living youth that states:
5

Ensuring the child's safety. Minimizing the trauma experienced by
the child and family during the placement process. Maintaining
continuity by placing the child with relatives and in their community
whenever possible.
Analysis Violation is not established as Calhoun County MDHHS provided
a placement in the community with a supportive person as an
independent living placement that was familiar with ILY. A
thorough assessment was completed on the Foster Parent, and it
was determined that ILY would be in a placement that ensured his
safety and minimized his trauma experienced during the
placement process.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
